entry.title: Christian "Chrigel" Maurer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Christian "Chrigel" Maurer (pictured), eight-time winner of the X-Alps "hike-and-fly" paragliding endurance race, and his future wife Karin both won gold medals at the same World Cup event?

entry.title: 1955 Brazilian coup d'état (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that due to the 1955 Brazilian coup d'état, Brazil had three presidents in the span of a single week?

entry.title: Joan Brigham (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that artist Joan Brigham is best known for her work with steam?

entry.title: Admiral Beatty Hotel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that following its closure, the former Admiral Beatty Hotel was converted into a senior citizens' apartment building?

entry.title: Mother Mary Corona (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that even though Mother Mary Corona received no formal teacher training, she was the president of Alverno Teachers College?

entry.title: Yanomamö: The Fierce People (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 1968 book Yanomamö: The Fierce People led to a major and decade-long controversy in the field of anthropology?

entry.title: Wade Meckler (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Major League Baseball player Wade Meckler was 4 feet 10 inches (1.47 metres) tall, and weighed 75 pounds (34 kilograms), as a high-school freshman?

entry.title: Jergins Trust Building (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd that once led to the Jergins Trust Building in Long Beach, California?
